NAME

perlguts - Introduction to the Perl API

DESCRIPTION

This document attempts to describe how to use the Perl API, as well as to provide some info on the basic workings of the Perl core. It is far from complete and probably contains many errors. Please refer any questions or comments to the author below.

Variables

Datatypes

Perl has three typedefs that handle Perl's three main data types:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV  Scalar Value
    AV  Array Value
    HV  Hash Value

Each typedef has specific routines that manipulate the various data types.

What is an "IV"?

Perl uses a special typedef IV which is a simple signed integer type that is guaranteed to be large enough to hold a pointer (as well as an integer). Additionally, there is the UV, which is simply an unsigned IV.

Perl also uses two special typedefs, I32 and I16, which will always be at least 32-bits and 16-bits long, respectively. (Again, there are U32 and U16, as well.) They will usually be exactly 32 and 16 bits long, but on Crays they will both be 64 bits.

Working with SVs

An SV can be created and loaded with one command. There are five types of values that can be loaded: an integer value (IV), an unsigned integer value (UV), a double (NV), a string (PV), and another scalar (SV). ("PV" stands for "Pointer Value". You might think that it is misnamed because it is described as pointing only to strings. However, it is possible to have it point to other things. For example, it could point to an array of UVs. But, using it for non-strings requires care, as the underlying assumption of much of the internals is that PVs are just for strings. Often, for example, a trailing http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

NUL is tacked on automatically. The non-string use is documented only in this paragraph.)

The seven routines are:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV*  newSViv(IV);
    SV*  newSVuv(UV);
    SV*  newSVnv(double);
    SV*  newSVpv(const char*, STRLEN);
    SV*  newSVpvn(const char*, STRLEN);
    SV*  newSVpvf(const char*, ...);
    SV*  newSVsv(SV*);

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

STRLEN is an integer type (Size_t, usually defined as size_t in config.h) guaranteed to be large enough to represent the size of any string that perl can handle.

In the unlikely case of a SV requiring more complex initialization, you can create an empty SV with newSV(len). If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

len is 0 an empty SV of type NULL is returned, else an SV of type PV is returned with len + 1 (for the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

NUL ) bytes of storage allocated, accessible via SvPVX. In both cases the SV has the undef value.

  1.     SV *sv = newSV(0);   /* no storage allocated  */
  2.     SV *sv = newSV(10);  /* 10 (+1) bytes of uninitialised storage
  3.                           * allocated */

To change the value of an already-existing SV, there are eight routines:

  1.     void  sv_setiv(SV*, IV);
  2.     void  sv_setuv(SV*, UV);
  3.     void  sv_setnv(SV*, double);
  4.     void  sv_setpv(SV*, const char*);
  5.     void  sv_setpvn(SV*, const char*, STRLEN)
  6.     void  sv_setpvf(SV*, const char*, ...);
  7.     void  sv_vsetpvfn(SV*, const char*, STRLEN, va_list *,
  8.                                                     SV **, I32, bool *);
  9.     void  sv_setsv(SV*, SV*);

Notice that you can choose to specify the length of the string to be assigned by using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_setpvn , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newSVpvn , or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newSVpv , or you may allow Perl to calculate the length by using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_setpv or by specifying 0 as the second argument to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newSVpv . Be warned, though, that Perl will determine the string's length by using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

strlen , which depends on the string terminating with a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

NUL character, and not otherwise containing NULs.

The arguments of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_setpvf are processed like sprintf, and the formatted output becomes the value.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_vsetpvfn is an analogue of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

vsprintf , but it allows you to specify either a pointer to a variable argument list or the address and length of an array of SVs. The last argument points to a boolean; on return, if that boolean is true, then locale-specific information has been used to format the string, and the string's contents are therefore untrustworthy (see perlsec). This pointer may be NULL if that information is not important. Note that this function requires you to specify the length of the format.

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_set*() functions are not generic enough to operate on values that have "magic". See Magic Virtual Tables later in this document.

All SVs that contain strings should be terminated with a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

NUL character. If it is not http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

NUL -terminated there is a risk of core dumps and corruptions from code which passes the string to C functions or system calls which expect a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

NUL -terminated string. Perl's own functions typically add a trailing http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

NUL for this reason. Nevertheless, you should be very careful when you pass a string stored in an SV to a C function or system call.

To access the actual value that an SV points to, you can use the macros:

  1.     SvIV(SV*)
  2.     SvUV(SV*)
  3.     SvNV(SV*)
  4.     SvPV(SV*, STRLEN len)
  5.     SvPV_nolen(SV*)

which will automatically coerce the actual scalar type into an IV, UV, double, or string.

In the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvPV macro, the length of the string returned is placed into the variable http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

len (this is a macro, so you do not use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&len ). If you do not care what the length of the data is, use the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvPV_nolen macro. Historically the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvPV macro with the global variable http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_na has been used in this case. But that can be quite inefficient because http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_na must be accessed in thread-local storage in threaded Perl. In any case, remember that Perl allows arbitrary strings of data that may both contain NULs and might not be terminated by a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

NUL .

Also remember that C doesn't allow you to safely say foo(SvPV(s, len), len);. It might work with your compiler, but it won't work for everyone. Break this sort of statement up into separate assignments:

  1.     SV *s;
  2.     STRLEN len;
  3.     char *ptr;
  4.     ptr = SvPV(s, len);
  5.     foo(ptr, len);

If you want to know if the scalar value is TRUE, you can use:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SvTRUE(SV*)

Although Perl will automatically grow strings for you, if you need to force Perl to allocate more memory for your SV, you can use the macro

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SvGROW(SV*, STRLEN newlen)

which will determine if more memory needs to be allocated. If so, it will call the function http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_grow . Note that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvGROW can only increase, not decrease, the allocated memory of an SV and that it does not automatically add space for the trailing http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

NUL byte (perl's own string functions typically do http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvGROW(sv, len + 1) ).

If you want to write to an existing SV's buffer and set its value to a string, use SvPV_force() or one of its variants to force the SV to be a PV. This will remove any of various types of non-stringness from the SV while preserving the content of the SV in the PV. This can be used, for example, to append data from an API function to a buffer without extra copying:

  1.     (void)SvPVbyte_force(sv, len);
  2.     s = SvGROW(sv, len + needlen + 1);
  3.     /* something that modifies up to needlen bytes at s+len, but
  4.        modifies newlen bytes
  5.          eg. newlen = read(fd, s + len, needlen);
  6.        ignoring errors for these examples
  7.      */
  8.     s[len + newlen] = '\0';
  9.     SvCUR_set(sv, len + newlen);
  10.     SvUTF8_off(sv);
  11.     SvSETMAGIC(sv);

If you already have the data in memory or if you want to keep your code simple, you can use one of the sv_cat*() variants, such as sv_catpvn(). If you want to insert anywhere in the string you can use sv_insert() or sv_insert_flags().

If you don't need the existing content of the SV, you can avoid some copying with:

  1.     sv_setpvn(sv, "", 0);
  2.     s = SvGROW(sv, needlen + 1);
  3.     /* something that modifies up to needlen bytes at s, but modifies
  4.        newlen bytes
  5.          eg. newlen = read(fd, s. needlen);
  6.      */
  7.     s[newlen] = '\0';
  8.     SvCUR_set(sv, newlen);
  9.     SvPOK_only(sv); /* also clears SVf_UTF8 */
  10.     SvSETMAGIC(sv);

Again, if you already have the data in memory or want to avoid the complexity of the above, you can use sv_setpvn().

If you have a buffer allocated with Newx() and want to set that as the SV's value, you can use sv_usepvn_flags(). That has some requirements if you want to avoid perl re-allocating the buffer to fit the trailing NUL:

  1.    Newx(buf, somesize+1, char);
  2.    /* ... fill in buf ... */
  3.    buf[somesize] = '\0';
  4.    sv_usepvn_flags(sv, buf, somesize, SV_SMAGIC | SV_HAS_TRAILING_NUL);
  5.    /* buf now belongs to perl, don't release it */

If you have an SV and want to know what kind of data Perl thinks is stored in it, you can use the following macros to check the type of SV you have.

  1.     SvIOK(SV*)
  2.     SvNOK(SV*)
  3.     SvPOK(SV*)

You can get and set the current length of the string stored in an SV with the following macros:

  1.     SvCUR(SV*)
  2.     SvCUR_set(SV*, I32 val)

You can also get a pointer to the end of the string stored in the SV with the macro:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SvEND(SV*)

But note that these last three macros are valid only if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvPOK() is true.

If you want to append something to the end of string stored in an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* , you can use the following functions:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    void  sv_catpv(SV*, const char*);
    void  sv_catpvn(SV*, const char*, STRLEN);
    void  sv_catpvf(SV*, const char*, ...);
    void  sv_vcatpvfn(SV*, const char*, STRLEN, va_list *, SV **,
                                                             I32, bool);
    void  sv_catsv(SV*, SV*);

The first function calculates the length of the string to be appended by using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

strlen . In the second, you specify the length of the string yourself. The third function processes its arguments like sprintf and appends the formatted output. The fourth function works like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

vsprintf . You can specify the address and length of an array of SVs instead of the va_list argument. The fifth function extends the string stored in the first SV with the string stored in the second SV. It also forces the second SV to be interpreted as a string.

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_cat*() functions are not generic enough to operate on values that have "magic". See Magic Virtual Tables later in this document.

If you know the name of a scalar variable, you can get a pointer to its SV by using the following:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV*  get_sv("package::varname", 0);

This returns NULL if the variable does not exist.

If you want to know if this variable (or any other SV) is actually defined, you can call:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SvOK(SV*)

The scalar undef value is stored in an SV instance called http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_sv_undef .

Its address can be used whenever an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* is needed. Make sure that you don't try to compare a random sv with http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_undef . For example when interfacing Perl code, it'll work correctly for:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

  foo(undef);

But won't work when called as:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

  $x = undef;
  foo($x);

So to repeat always use SvOK() to check whether an sv is defined.

Also you have to be careful when using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_undef as a value in AVs or HVs (see AVs, HVs and undefined values).

There are also the two values http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_sv_yes and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_sv_no , which contain boolean TRUE and FALSE values, respectively. Like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_sv_undef , their addresses can be used whenever an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* is needed.

Do not be fooled into thinking that (SV *) 0 is the same as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_undef . Take this code:

  1.     SV* sv = (SV*) 0;
  2.     if (I-am-to-return-a-real-value) {
  3.             sv = sv_2mortal(newSViv(42));
  4.     }
  5.     sv_setsv(ST(0), sv);

This code tries to return a new SV (which contains the value 42) if it should return a real value, or undef otherwise. Instead it has returned a NULL pointer which, somewhere down the line, will cause a segmentation violation, bus error, or just weird results. Change the zero to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_undef in the first line and all will be well.

To free an SV that you've created, call http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvREFCNT_dec(SV*) . Normally this call is not necessary (see Reference Counts and Mortality).

Offsets

Perl provides the function http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_chop to efficiently remove characters from the beginning of a string; you give it an SV and a pointer to somewhere inside the PV, and it discards everything before the pointer. The efficiency comes by means of a little hack: instead of actually removing the characters, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_chop sets the flag http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

OOK (offset OK) to signal to other functions that the offset hack is in effect, and it moves the PV pointer (called http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvPVX ) forward by the number of bytes chopped off, and adjusts http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvCUR and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvLEN accordingly. (A portion of the space between the old and new PV pointers is used to store the count of chopped bytes.)

Hence, at this point, the start of the buffer that we allocated lives at http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvPVX(sv) - SvIV(sv) in memory and the PV pointer is pointing into the middle of this allocated storage.

This is best demonstrated by example. Normally copy-on-write will prevent the substitution from operator from using this hack, but if you can craft a string for which copy-on-write is not possible, you can see it in play. In the current implementation, the final byte of a string buffer is used as a copy-on-write reference count. If the buffer is not big enough, then copy-on-write is skipped. First have a look at an empty string:

  1.   % ./perl -Ilib -MDevel::Peek -le '$a=""; $a .= ""; Dump $a'
  2.   SV = PV(0x7ffb7c008a70) at 0x7ffb7c030390
  3.     REFCNT = 1
  4.     FLAGS = (POK,pPOK)
  5.     PV = 0x7ffb7bc05b50 ""\0
  6.     CUR = 0
  7.     LEN = 10

Notice here the LEN is 10. (It may differ on your platform.) Extend the length of the string to one less than 10, and do a substitution:

  1.  % ./perl -Ilib -MDevel::Peek -le '$a=""; $a.="123456789"; $a=~s/.//; \
  2.                                                             Dump($a)'
  3.  SV = PV(0x7ffa04008a70) at 0x7ffa04030390
  4.    REFCNT = 1
  5.    FLAGS = (POK,OOK,pPOK)
  6.    OFFSET = 1
  7.    PV = 0x7ffa03c05b61 ( "\1" . ) "23456789"\0
  8.    CUR = 8
  9.    LEN = 9

Here the number of bytes chopped off (1) is shown next as the OFFSET. The portion of the string between the "real" and the "fake" beginnings is shown in parentheses, and the values of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvCUR and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvLEN reflect the fake beginning, not the real one. (The first character of the string buffer happens to have changed to "\1" here, not "1", because the current implementation stores the offset count in the string buffer. This is subject to change.)

Something similar to the offset hack is performed on AVs to enable efficient shifting and splicing off the beginning of the array; while http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

AvARRAY points to the first element in the array that is visible from Perl, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

AvALLOC points to the real start of the C array. These are usually the same, but a shift operation can be carried out by increasing http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

AvARRAY by one and decreasing http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

AvFILL and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

AvMAX . Again, the location of the real start of the C array only comes into play when freeing the array. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_shift in av.c.

What's Really Stored in an SV?

Recall that the usual method of determining the type of scalar you have is to use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Sv*OK macros. Because a scalar can be both a number and a string, usually these macros will always return TRUE and calling the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Sv*V macros will do the appropriate conversion of string to integer/double or integer/double to string.

If you really need to know if you have an integer, double, or string pointer in an SV, you can use the following three macros instead:

  1.     SvIOKp(SV*)
  2.     SvNOKp(SV*)
  3.     SvPOKp(SV*)

These will tell you if you truly have an integer, double, or string pointer stored in your SV. The "p" stands for private.

There are various ways in which the private and public flags may differ. For example, in perl 5.16 and earlier a tied SV may have a valid underlying value in the IV slot (so SvIOKp is true), but the data should be accessed via the FETCH routine rather than directly, so SvIOK is false. (In perl 5.18 onwards, tied scalars use the flags the same way as untied scalars.) Another is when numeric conversion has occurred and precision has been lost: only the private flag is set on 'lossy' values. So when an NV is converted to an IV with loss, SvIOKp, SvNOKp and SvNOK will be set, while SvIOK wont be.

In general, though, it's best to use the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Sv*V macros.

Working with AVs

There are two ways to create and load an AV. The first method creates an empty AV:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    AV*  newAV();

The second method both creates the AV and initially populates it with SVs:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    AV*  av_make(SSize_t num, SV **ptr);

The second argument points to an array containing http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

num http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* 's. Once the AV has been created, the SVs can be destroyed, if so desired.

Once the AV has been created, the following operations are possible on it:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    void  av_push(AV*, SV*);
    SV*   av_pop(AV*);
    SV*   av_shift(AV*);
    void  av_unshift(AV*, SSize_t num);

These should be familiar operations, with the exception of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_unshift . This routine adds http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

num elements at the front of the array with the undef value. You must then use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_store (described below) to assign values to these new elements.

Here are some other functions:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SSize_t av_top_index(AV*);
    SV**    av_fetch(AV*, SSize_t key, I32 lval);
    SV**    av_store(AV*, SSize_t key, SV* val);

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_top_index function returns the highest index value in an array (just like $#array in Perl). If the array is empty, -1 is returned. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_fetch function returns the value at index http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

key , but if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

lval is non-zero, then http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_fetch will store an undef value at that index. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_store function stores the value http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

val at index http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

key , and does not increment the reference count of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

val . Thus the caller is responsible for taking care of that, and if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_store returns NULL, the caller will have to decrement the reference count to avoid a memory leak. Note that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_fetch and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_store both return http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV** 's, not http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* 's as their return value.

A few more:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    void  av_clear(AV*);
    void  av_undef(AV*);
    void  av_extend(AV*, SSize_t key);

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_clear function deletes all the elements in the AV* array, but does not actually delete the array itself. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_undef function will delete all the elements in the array plus the array itself. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

av_extend function extends the array so that it contains at least http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

key+1 elements. If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

key+1 is less than the currently allocated length of the array, then nothing is done.

If you know the name of an array variable, you can get a pointer to its AV by using the following:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    AV*  get_av("package::varname", 0);

This returns NULL if the variable does not exist.

See Understanding the Magic of Tied Hashes and Arrays for more information on how to use the array access functions on tied arrays.

Working with HVs

To create an HV, you use the following routine:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    HV*  newHV();

Once the HV has been created, the following operations are possible on it:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV**  hv_store(HV*, const char* key, U32 klen, SV* val, U32 hash);
    SV**  hv_fetch(HV*, const char* key, U32 klen, I32 lval);

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

klen parameter is the length of the key being passed in (Note that you cannot pass 0 in as a value of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

klen to tell Perl to measure the length of the key). The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

val argument contains the SV pointer to the scalar being stored, and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hash is the precomputed hash value (zero if you want http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hv_store to calculate it for you). The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

lval parameter indicates whether this fetch is actually a part of a store operation, in which case a new undefined value will be added to the HV with the supplied key and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hv_fetch will return as if the value had already existed.

Remember that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hv_store and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hv_fetch return http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV** 's and not just http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* . To access the scalar value, you must first dereference the return value. However, you should check to make sure that the return value is not NULL before dereferencing it.

The first of these two functions checks if a hash table entry exists, and the second deletes it.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    bool  hv_exists(HV*, const char* key, U32 klen);
    SV*   hv_delete(HV*, const char* key, U32 klen, I32 flags);

If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

flags does not include the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

G_DISCARD flag then http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hv_delete will create and return a mortal copy of the deleted value.

And more miscellaneous functions:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    void   hv_clear(HV*);
    void   hv_undef(HV*);

Like their AV counterparts, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hv_clear deletes all the entries in the hash table but does not actually delete the hash table. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hv_undef deletes both the entries and the hash table itself.

Perl keeps the actual data in a linked list of structures with a typedef of HE. These contain the actual key and value pointers (plus extra administrative overhead). The key is a string pointer; the value is an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* . However, once you have an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

HE* , to get the actual key and value, use the routines specified below.

  1.     I32    hv_iterinit(HV*);
  2.             /* Prepares starting point to traverse hash table */
  3.     HE*    hv_iternext(HV*);
  4.             /* Get the next entry, and return a pointer to a
  5.                structure that has both the key and value */
  6.     char*  hv_iterkey(HE* entry, I32* retlen);
  7.             /* Get the key from an HE structure and also return
  8.                the length of the key string */
  9.     SV*    hv_iterval(HV*, HE* entry);
  10.             /* Return an SV pointer to the value of the HE
  11.                structure */
  12.     SV*    hv_iternextsv(HV*, char** key, I32* retlen);
  13.             /* This convenience routine combines hv_iternext,
  14. 	       hv_iterkey, and hv_iterval.  The key and retlen
  15. 	       arguments are return values for the key and its
  16. 	       length.  The value is returned in the SV* argument */

If you know the name of a hash variable, you can get a pointer to its HV by using the following:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    HV*  get_hv("package::varname", 0);

This returns NULL if the variable does not exist.

The hash algorithm is defined in the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PERL_HASH macro:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    PERL_HASH(hash, key, klen)

The exact implementation of this macro varies by architecture and version of perl, and the return value may change per invocation, so the value is only valid for the duration of a single perl process.

See Understanding the Magic of Tied Hashes and Arrays for more information on how to use the hash access functions on tied hashes.

Hash API Extensions

Beginning with version 5.004, the following functions are also supported:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    HE*     hv_fetch_ent  (HV* tb, SV* key, I32 lval, U32 hash);
    HE*     hv_store_ent  (HV* tb, SV* key, SV* val, U32 hash);

    bool    hv_exists_ent (HV* tb, SV* key, U32 hash);
    SV*     hv_delete_ent (HV* tb, SV* key, I32 flags, U32 hash);

    SV*     hv_iterkeysv  (HE* entry);

Note that these functions take http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* keys, which simplifies writing of extension code that deals with hash structures. These functions also allow passing of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* keys to tie functions without forcing you to stringify the keys (unlike the previous set of functions).

They also return and accept whole hash entries (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

HE* ), making their use more efficient (since the hash number for a particular string doesn't have to be recomputed every time). See perlapi for detailed descriptions.

The following macros must always be used to access the contents of hash entries. Note that the arguments to these macros must be simple variables, since they may get evaluated more than once. See perlapi for detailed descriptions of these macros.

  1.     HePV(HE* he, STRLEN len)
  2.     HeVAL(HE* he)
  3.     HeHASH(HE* he)
  4.     HeSVKEY(HE* he)
  5.     HeSVKEY_force(HE* he)
  6.     HeSVKEY_set(HE* he, SV* sv)

These two lower level macros are defined, but must only be used when dealing with keys that are not http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* s:

  1.     HeKEY(HE* he)
  2.     HeKLEN(HE* he)

Note that both http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hv_store and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hv_store_ent do not increment the reference count of the stored http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

val , which is the caller's responsibility. If these functions return a NULL value, the caller will usually have to decrement the reference count of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

val to avoid a memory leak.

AVs, HVs and undefined values

Sometimes you have to store undefined values in AVs or HVs. Although this may be a rare case, it can be tricky. That's because you're used to using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_undef if you need an undefined SV.

For example, intuition tells you that this XS code:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    AV *av = newAV();
    av_store( av, 0, &PL_sv_undef );

is equivalent to this Perl code:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    my @av;
    $av[0] = undef;

Unfortunately, this isn't true. In perl 5.18 and earlier, AVs use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_undef as a marker for indicating that an array element has not yet been initialized. Thus, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

exists $av[0] would be true for the above Perl code, but false for the array generated by the XS code. In perl 5.20, storing &PL_sv_undef will create a read-only element, because the scalar &PL_sv_undef itself is stored, not a copy.

Similar problems can occur when storing http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_undef in HVs:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    hv_store( hv, "key", 3, &PL_sv_undef, 0 );

This will indeed make the value undef, but if you try to modify the value of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

key , you'll get the following error:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    Modification of non-creatable hash value attempted

In perl 5.8.0, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_undef was also used to mark placeholders in restricted hashes. This caused such hash entries not to appear when iterating over the hash or when checking for the keys with the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

hv_exists function.

You can run into similar problems when you store http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_yes or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_no into AVs or HVs. Trying to modify such elements will give you the following error:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    Modification of a read-only value attempted

To make a long story short, you can use the special variables http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_undef , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_yes and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_no with AVs and HVs, but you have to make sure you know what you're doing.

Generally, if you want to store an undefined value in an AV or HV, you should not use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

&PL_sv_undef , but rather create a new undefined value using the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newSV function, for example:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    av_store( av, 42, newSV(0) );
    hv_store( hv, "foo", 3, newSV(0), 0 );

References

References are a special type of scalar that point to other data types (including other references).

To create a reference, use either of the following functions:

  1.     SV* newRV_inc((SV*) thing);
  2.     SV* newRV_noinc((SV*) thing);

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

thing argument can be any of an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

AV* , or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

HV* . The functions are identical except that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newRV_inc increments the reference count of the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

thing , while http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newRV_noinc does not. For historical reasons, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newRV is a synonym for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newRV_inc .

Once you have a reference, you can use the following macro to dereference the reference:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SvRV(SV*)

then call the appropriate routines, casting the returned http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* to either an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

AV* or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

HV* , if required.

To determine if an SV is a reference, you can use the following macro:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SvROK(SV*)

To discover what type of value the reference refers to, use the following macro and then check the return value.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SvTYPE(SvRV(SV*))

The most useful types that will be returned are:

  1.     < SVt_PVAV  Scalar
  2.     SVt_PVAV    Array
  3.     SVt_PVHV    Hash
  4.     SVt_PVCV    Code
  5.     SVt_PVGV    Glob (possibly a file handle)

See svtype in perlapi for more details.

Blessed References and Class Objects

References are also used to support object-oriented programming. In perl's OO lexicon, an object is simply a reference that has been blessed into a package (or class). Once blessed, the programmer may now use the reference to access the various methods in the class.

A reference can be blessed into a package with the following function:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV* sv_bless(SV* sv, HV* stash);

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv argument must be a reference value. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

stash argument specifies which class the reference will belong to. See Stashes and Globs for information on converting class names into stashes.

/* Still under construction */

The following function upgrades rv to reference if not already one. Creates a new SV for rv to point to. If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

classname is non-null, the SV is blessed into the specified class. SV is returned.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

	SV* newSVrv(SV* rv, const char* classname);

The following three functions copy integer, unsigned integer or double into an SV whose reference is http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

rv . SV is blessed if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

classname is non-null.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

	SV* sv_setref_iv(SV* rv, const char* classname, IV iv);
	SV* sv_setref_uv(SV* rv, const char* classname, UV uv);
	SV* sv_setref_nv(SV* rv, const char* classname, NV iv);

The following function copies the pointer value (the address, not the string!) into an SV whose reference is rv. SV is blessed if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

classname is non-null.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

The following function copies a string into an SV whose reference is http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

rv . Set length to 0 to let Perl calculate the string length. SV is blessed if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

classname is non-null.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV* sv_setref_pvn(SV* rv, const char* classname, char* pv,
                                                         STRLEN length);

The following function tests whether the SV is blessed into the specified class. It does not check inheritance relationships.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

	int  sv_isa(SV* sv, const char* name);

The following function tests whether the SV is a reference to a blessed object.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

	int  sv_isobject(SV* sv);

The following function tests whether the SV is derived from the specified class. SV can be either a reference to a blessed object or a string containing a class name. perltidy

UNIVERSAL::isa functionality.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

	bool sv_derived_from(SV* sv, const char* name);

To check if you've got an object derived from a specific class you have to write:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

	if (sv_isobject(sv) && sv_derived_from(sv, class)) { ... }

Creating New Variables

To create a new Perl variable with an undef value which can be accessed from your Perl script, use the following routines, depending on the variable type.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV*  get_sv("package::varname", GV_ADD);
    AV*  get_av("package::varname", GV_ADD);
    HV*  get_hv("package::varname", GV_ADD);

Notice the use of GV_ADD as the second parameter. The new variable can now be set, using the routines appropriate to the data type.

There are additional macros whose values may be bitwise OR'ed with the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

GV_ADD argument to enable certain extra features. Those bits are:

  • GV_ADDMULTI

    Marks the variable as multiply defined, thus preventing the:

    1.   Name <varname> used only once: possible typo

    warning.

  • GV_ADDWARN

    Issues the warning:

    1.   Had to create <varname> unexpectedly

    if the variable did not exist before the function was called.

If you do not specify a package name, the variable is created in the current package.

Reference Counts and Mortality

Perl uses a reference count-driven garbage collection mechanism. SVs, AVs, or HVs (xV for short in the following) start their life with a reference count of 1. If the reference count of an xV ever drops to 0, then it will be destroyed and its memory made available for reuse.

This normally doesn't happen at the Perl level unless a variable is undef'ed or the last variable holding a reference to it is changed or overwritten. At the internal level, however, reference counts can be manipulated with the following macros:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    int SvREFCNT(SV* sv);
    SV* SvREFCNT_inc(SV* sv);
    void SvREFCNT_dec(SV* sv);

However, there is one other function which manipulates the reference count of its argument. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newRV_inc function, you will recall, creates a reference to the specified argument. As a side effect, it increments the argument's reference count. If this is not what you want, use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newRV_noinc instead.

For example, imagine you want to return a reference from an XSUB function. Inside the XSUB routine, you create an SV which initially has a reference count of one. Then you call http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newRV_inc , passing it the just-created SV. This returns the reference as a new SV, but the reference count of the SV you passed to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newRV_inc has been incremented to two. Now you return the reference from the XSUB routine and forget about the SV. But Perl hasn't! Whenever the returned reference is destroyed, the reference count of the original SV is decreased to one and nothing happens. The SV will hang around without any way to access it until Perl itself terminates. This is a memory leak.

The correct procedure, then, is to use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newRV_noinc instead of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

newRV_inc . Then, if and when the last reference is destroyed, the reference count of the SV will go to zero and it will be destroyed, stopping any memory leak.

There are some convenience functions available that can help with the destruction of xVs. These functions introduce the concept of "mortality". An xV that is mortal has had its reference count marked to be decremented, but not actually decremented, until "a short time later". Generally the term "short time later" means a single Perl statement, such as a call to an XSUB function. The actual determinant for when mortal xVs have their reference count decremented depends on two macros, SAVETMPS and FREETMPS. See perlcall and perlxs for more details on these macros.

"Mortalization" then is at its simplest a deferred http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvREFCNT_dec . However, if you mortalize a variable twice, the reference count will later be decremented twice.

"Mortal" SVs are mainly used for SVs that are placed on perl's stack. For example an SV which is created just to pass a number to a called sub is made mortal to have it cleaned up automatically when it's popped off the stack. Similarly, results returned by XSUBs (which are pushed on the stack) are often made mortal.

To create a mortal variable, use the functions:

  1.     SV*  sv_newmortal()
  2.     SV*  sv_2mortal(SV*)
  3.     SV*  sv_mortalcopy(SV*)

The first call creates a mortal SV (with no value), the second converts an existing SV to a mortal SV (and thus defers a call to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvREFCNT_dec ), and the third creates a mortal copy of an existing SV. Because http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_newmortal gives the new SV no value, it must normally be given one via http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_setpv , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_setiv , etc. :

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV *tmp = sv_newmortal();
    sv_setiv(tmp, an_integer);

As that is multiple C statements it is quite common so see this idiom instead:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV *tmp = sv_2mortal(newSViv(an_integer));

You should be careful about creating mortal variables. Strange things can happen if you make the same value mortal within multiple contexts, or if you make a variable mortal multiple times. Thinking of "Mortalization" as deferred http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvREFCNT_dec should help to minimize such problems. For example if you are passing an SV which you know has a high enough REFCNT to survive its use on the stack you need not do any mortalization. If you are not sure then doing an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvREFCNT_inc and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_2mortal , or making a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_mortalcopy is safer.

The mortal routines are not just for SVs; AVs and HVs can be made mortal by passing their address (type-casted to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* ) to the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_2mortal or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_mortalcopy routines.

Stashes and Globs

A stash is a hash that contains all variables that are defined within a package. Each key of the stash is a symbol name (shared by all the different types of objects that have the same name), and each value in the hash table is a GV (Glob Value). This GV in turn contains references to the various objects of that name, including (but not limited to) the following:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    Scalar Value
    Array Value
    Hash Value
    I/O Handle
    Format
    Subroutine

There is a single stash called http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_defstash that holds the items that exist in the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

main package. To get at the items in other packages, append the string "::" to the package name. The items in the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Foo package are in the stash http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Foo:: in PL_defstash. The items in the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Bar::Baz package are in the stash http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Baz:: in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Bar:: 's stash.

To get the stash pointer for a particular package, use the function:

  1.     HV*  gv_stashpv(const char* name, I32 flags)
  2.     HV*  gv_stashsv(SV*, I32 flags)

The first function takes a literal string, the second uses the string stored in the SV. Remember that a stash is just a hash table, so you get back an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

HV* . The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

flags flag will create a new package if it is set to GV_ADD.

The name that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

gv_stash*v wants is the name of the package whose symbol table you want. The default package is called http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

main . If you have multiply nested packages, pass their names to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

gv_stash*v , separated by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

:: as in the Perl language itself.

Alternately, if you have an SV that is a blessed reference, you can find out the stash pointer by using:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    HV*  SvSTASH(SvRV(SV*));

then use the following to get the package name itself:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    char*  HvNAME(HV* stash);

If you need to bless or re-bless an object you can use the following function:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV*  sv_bless(SV*, HV* stash)

where the first argument, an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* , must be a reference, and the second argument is a stash. The returned http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* can now be used in the same way as any other SV.

For more information on references and blessings, consult perlref.

Double-Typed SVs

Scalar variables normally contain only one type of value, an integer, double, pointer, or reference. Perl will automatically convert the actual scalar data from the stored type into the requested type.

Some scalar variables contain more than one type of scalar data. For example, the variable http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$! contains either the numeric value of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

errno or its string equivalent from either http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

strerror or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sys_errlist[] .

To force multiple data values into an SV, you must do two things: use the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_set*v routines to add the additional scalar type, then set a flag so that Perl will believe it contains more than one type of data. The four macros to set the flags are:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

	SvIOK_on
	SvNOK_on
	SvPOK_on
	SvROK_on

The particular macro you must use depends on which http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_set*v routine you called first. This is because every http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_set*v routine turns on only the bit for the particular type of data being set, and turns off all the rest.

For example, to create a new Perl variable called "dberror" that contains both the numeric and descriptive string error values, you could use the following code:

  1.     extern int  dberror;
  2.     extern char *dberror_list;
  4.     SV* sv = get_sv("dberror", GV_ADD);
  5.     sv_setiv(sv, (IV) dberror);
  6.     sv_setpv(sv, dberror_list[dberror]);
  7.     SvIOK_on(sv);

If the order of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_setiv and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_setpv had been reversed, then the macro http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvPOK_on would need to be called instead of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvIOK_on .

Read-Only Values

In Perl 5.16 and earlier, copy-on-write (see the next section) shared a flag bit with read-only scalars. So the only way to test whether http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_setsv , etc., will raise a "Modification of a read-only value" error in those versions is:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SvREADONLY(sv) && !SvIsCOW(sv)

Under Perl 5.18 and later, SvREADONLY only applies to read-only variables, and, under 5.20, copy-on-write scalars can also be read-only, so the above check is incorrect. You just want:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SvREADONLY(sv)

If you need to do this check often, define your own macro like this:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    #if PERL_VERSION >= 18
    # define SvTRULYREADONLY(sv) SvREADONLY(sv)
    #else
    # define SvTRULYREADONLY(sv) (SvREADONLY(sv) && !SvIsCOW(sv))
    #endif

Copy on Write

Perl implements a copy-on-write (COW) mechanism for scalars, in which string copies are not immediately made when requested, but are deferred until made necessary by one or the other scalar changing. This is mostly transparent, but one must take care not to modify string buffers that are shared by multiple SVs.

You can test whether an SV is using copy-on-write with http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvIsCOW(sv) .

You can force an SV to make its own copy of its string buffer by calling http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_force_normal(sv) or SvPV_force_nolen(sv).

If you want to make the SV drop its string buffer, use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_force_normal_flags(sv, SV_COW_DROP_PV) or simply http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_setsv(sv, NULL) .

All of these functions will croak on read-only scalars (see the previous section for more on those).

To test that your code is behaving correctly and not modifying COW buffers, on systems that support mmap(2) (i.e., Unix) you can configure perl with http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

-Accflags=-DPERL_DEBUG_READONLY_COW and it will turn buffer violations into crashes. You will find it to be marvellously slow, so you may want to skip perl's own tests.

Magic Variables

[This section still under construction. Ignore everything here. Post no bills. Everything not permitted is forbidden.]

Any SV may be magical, that is, it has special features that a normal SV does not have. These features are stored in the SV structure in a linked list of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

struct magic 's, typedef'ed to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

MAGIC .

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    struct magic {
        MAGIC*      mg_moremagic;
        MGVTBL*     mg_virtual;
        U16         mg_private;
        char        mg_type;
        U8          mg_flags;
        I32         mg_len;
        SV*         mg_obj;
        char*       mg_ptr;
    };

Note this is current as of patchlevel 0, and could change at any time.

Assigning Magic

Perl adds magic to an SV using the sv_magic function:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

  void sv_magic(SV* sv, SV* obj, int how, const char* name, I32 namlen);

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv argument is a pointer to the SV that is to acquire a new magical feature.

If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv is not already magical, Perl uses the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvUPGRADE macro to convert http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv to type http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SVt_PVMG . Perl then continues by adding new magic to the beginning of the linked list of magical features. Any prior entry of the same type of magic is deleted. Note that this can be overridden, and multiple instances of the same type of magic can be associated with an SV.

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

name and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

perltidy

perltidy

mg_len field and if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

perltidy

perltidy

perltidy

perltidy

perltidy

(name && namlen == HEf_SVKEY) then http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

name is assumed to contain an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SV* and is stored as-is with its REFCNT incremented.

The sv_magic function uses http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

mg_virtual field. See the Magic Virtual Tables section below. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

Note that before these macros were added, Perl internals used to directly use character literals, so you may occasionally come across old code or documentation referring to 'U' magic rather than http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy
