How multiple interpreters and concurrency are supported

Background and PERL_IMPLICIT_CONTEXT

The Perl interpreter can be regarded as a closed box: it has an API for feeding it code or otherwise making it do things, but it also has functions for its own use. This smells a lot like an object, and there are ways for you to build Perl so that you can have multiple interpreters, with one interpreter represented either as a C structure, or inside a thread-specific structure. These structures contain all the context, the state of that interpreter.

One macro controls the major Perl build flavor: MULTIPLICITY. The MULTIPLICITY build has a C structure that packages all the interpreter state. With multiplicity-enabled perls, PERL_IMPLICIT_CONTEXT is also normally defined, and enables the support for passing in a "hidden" first argument that represents all three data structures. MULTIPLICITY makes multi-threaded perls possible (with the ithreads threading model, related to the macro USE_ITHREADS.)

Two other "encapsulation" macros are the PERL_GLOBAL_STRUCT and PERL_GLOBAL_STRUCT_PRIVATE (the latter turns on the former, and the former turns on MULTIPLICITY.) The PERL_GLOBAL_STRUCT causes all the internal variables of Perl to be wrapped inside a single global struct, struct perl_vars, accessible as (globals) &PL_Vars or PL_VarsPtr or the function Perl_GetVars(). The PERL_GLOBAL_STRUCT_PRIVATE goes one step further, there is still a single struct (allocated in main() either from heap or from stack) but there are no global data symbols pointing to it. In either case the global struct should be initialized as the very first thing in main() using Perl_init_global_struct() and correspondingly tear it down after perl_free() using Perl_free_global_struct(), please see miniperlmain.c for usage details. You may also need to use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dVAR in your coding to "declare the global variables" when you are using them. dTHX does this for you automatically.

To see whether you have non-const data you can use a BSD (or GNU) compatible http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

nm :

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

  nm libperl.a | grep -v ' [TURtr] '

If this displays any http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

D or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

d symbols (or possibly http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

C or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

c ), you have non-const data. The symbols the grep removed are as follows: http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Tt are text, or code, the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Rr are read-only (const) data, and the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

U is <undefined>, external symbols referred to.

The test t/porting/libperl.t does this kind of symbol sanity checking on http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

libperl.a .

For backward compatibility reasons defining just PERL_GLOBAL_STRUCT doesn't actually hide all symbols inside a big global struct: some PerlIO_xxx vtables are left visible. The PERL_GLOBAL_STRUCT_PRIVATE then hides everything (see how the PERLIO_FUNCS_DECL is used).

All this obviously requires a way for the Perl internal functions to be either subroutines taking some kind of structure as the first argument, or subroutines taking nothing as the first argument. To enable these two very different ways of building the interpreter, the Perl source (as it does in so many other situations) makes heavy use of macros and subroutine naming conventions.

First problem: deciding which functions will be public API functions and which will be private. All functions whose names begin http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

S_ are private (think "S" for "secret" or "static"). All other functions begin with "Perl_", but just because a function begins with "Perl_" does not mean it is part of the API. (See Internal Functions.) The easiest way to be sure a function is part of the API is to find its entry in perlapi. If it exists in perlapi, it's part of the API. If it doesn't, and you think it should be (i.e., you need it for your extension), send mail via perlbug explaining why you think it should be.

Second problem: there must be a syntax so that the same subroutine declarations and calls can pass a structure as their first argument, or pass nothing. To solve this, the subroutines are named and declared in a particular way. Here's a typical start of a static function used within the Perl guts:

  1.   STATIC void
  2.   S_incline(pTHX_ char *s)

STATIC becomes "static" in C, and may be #define'd to nothing in some configurations in the future.

A public function (i.e. part of the internal API, but not necessarily sanctioned for use in extensions) begins like this:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

  void
  Perl_sv_setiv(pTHX_ SV* dsv, IV num)

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pTHX_ is one of a number of macros (in perl.h) that hide the details of the interpreter's context. THX stands for "thread", "this", or "thingy", as the case may be. (And no, George Lucas is not involved. :-) The first character could be 'p' for a prototype, 'a' for argument, or 'd' for declaration, so we have http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pTHX , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

aTHX and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dTHX , and their variants.

When Perl is built without options that set PERL_IMPLICIT_CONTEXT, there is no first argument containing the interpreter's context. The trailing underscore in the pTHX_ macro indicates that the macro expansion needs a comma after the context argument because other arguments follow it. If PERL_IMPLICIT_CONTEXT is not defined, pTHX_ will be ignored, and the subroutine is not prototyped to take the extra argument. The form of the macro without the trailing underscore is used when there are no additional explicit arguments.

When a core function calls another, it must pass the context. This is normally hidden via macros. Consider http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

sv_setiv . It expands into something like this:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    #ifdef PERL_IMPLICIT_CONTEXT
      #define sv_setiv(a,b)      Perl_sv_setiv(aTHX_ a, b)
      /* can't do this for vararg functions, see below */
    #else
      #define sv_setiv           Perl_sv_setiv
    #endif

This works well, and means that XS authors can gleefully write:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    sv_setiv(foo, bar);

and still have it work under all the modes Perl could have been compiled with.

This doesn't work so cleanly for varargs functions, though, as macros imply that the number of arguments is known in advance. Instead we either need to spell them out fully, passing http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

aTHX_ as the first argument (the Perl core tends to do this with functions like Perl_warner), or use a context-free version.

The context-free version of Perl_warner is called Perl_warner_nocontext, and does not take the extra argument. Instead it does dTHX; to get the context from thread-local storage. We http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

#define warner Perl_warner_nocontext so that extensions get source compatibility at the expense of performance. (Passing an arg is cheaper than grabbing it from thread-local storage.)

You can ignore [pad]THXx when browsing the Perl headers/sources. Those are strictly for use within the core. Extensions and embedders need only be aware of [pad]THX.

So what happened to dTHR?

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dTHR was introduced in perl 5.005 to support the older thread model. The older thread model now uses the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

THX mechanism to pass context pointers around, so http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dTHR is not useful any more. Perl 5.6.0 and later still have it for backward source compatibility, but it is defined to be a no-op.

How do I use all this in extensions?

When Perl is built with PERL_IMPLICIT_CONTEXT, extensions that call any functions in the Perl API will need to pass the initial context argument somehow. The kicker is that you will need to write it in such a way that the extension still compiles when Perl hasn't been built with PERL_IMPLICIT_CONTEXT enabled.

There are three ways to do this. First, the easy but inefficient way, which is also the default, in order to maintain source compatibility with extensions: whenever XSUB.h is #included, it redefines the aTHX and aTHX_ macros to call a function that will return the context. Thus, something like:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

        sv_setiv(sv, num);

in your extension will translate to this when PERL_IMPLICIT_CONTEXT is in effect:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

        Perl_sv_setiv(Perl_get_context(), sv, num);

or to this otherwise:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

        Perl_sv_setiv(sv, num);

You don't have to do anything new in your extension to get this; since the Perl library provides Perl_get_context(), it will all just work.

The second, more efficient way is to use the following template for your Foo.xs:

  1.         #define PERL_NO_GET_CONTEXT     /* we want efficiency */
  2.         #include "EXTERN.h"
  3.         #include "perl.h"
  4.         #include "XSUB.h"
  6.         STATIC void my_private_function(int arg1, int arg2);
  8.         STATIC void
  9.         my_private_function(int arg1, int arg2)
  10.         {
  11.             dTHX;       /* fetch context */
  12.             ... call many Perl API functions ...
  13.         }
  15.         [... etc ...]
  17.         MODULE = Foo            PACKAGE = Foo
  19.         /* typical XSUB */
  21.         void
  22.         my_xsub(arg)
  23.                 int arg
  24.             CODE:
  25.                 my_private_function(arg, 10);

Note that the only two changes from the normal way of writing an extension is the addition of a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

#define PERL_NO_GET_CONTEXT before including the Perl headers, followed by a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dTHX; declaration at the start of every function that will call the Perl API. (You'll know which functions need this, because the C compiler will complain that there's an undeclared identifier in those functions.) No changes are needed for the XSUBs themselves, because the XS() macro is correctly defined to pass in the implicit context if needed.

The third, even more efficient way is to ape how it is done within the Perl guts:

  1.         #define PERL_NO_GET_CONTEXT     /* we want efficiency */
  2.         #include "EXTERN.h"
  3.         #include "perl.h"
  4.         #include "XSUB.h"
  6.         /* pTHX_ only needed for functions that call Perl API */
  7.         STATIC void my_private_function(pTHX_ int arg1, int arg2);
  9.         STATIC void
  10.         my_private_function(pTHX_ int arg1, int arg2)
  11.         {
  12.             /* dTHX; not needed here, because THX is an argument */
  13.             ... call Perl API functions ...
  14.         }
  16.         [... etc ...]
  18.         MODULE = Foo            PACKAGE = Foo
  20.         /* typical XSUB */
  22.         void
  23.         my_xsub(arg)
  24.                 int arg
  25.             CODE:
  26.                 my_private_function(aTHX_ arg, 10);

This implementation never has to fetch the context using a function call, since it is always passed as an extra argument. Depending on your needs for simplicity or efficiency, you may mix the previous two approaches freely.

Never add a comma after http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pTHX yourself--always use the form of the macro with the underscore for functions that take explicit arguments, or the form without the argument for functions with no explicit arguments.

If one is compiling Perl with the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

-DPERL_GLOBAL_STRUCT the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dVAR definition is needed if the Perl global variables (see perlvars.h or globvar.sym) are accessed in the function and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dTHX is not used (the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dTHX includes the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dVAR if necessary). One notices the need for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dVAR only with the said compile-time define, because otherwise the Perl global variables are visible as-is.

Should I do anything special if I call perl from multiple threads?

If you create interpreters in one thread and then proceed to call them in another, you need to make sure perl's own Thread Local Storage (TLS) slot is initialized correctly in each of those threads.

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

perl_alloc and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

perl_clone API functions will automatically set the TLS slot to the interpreter they created, so that there is no need to do anything special if the interpreter is always accessed in the same thread that created it, and that thread did not create or call any other interpreters afterwards. If that is not the case, you have to set the TLS slot of the thread before calling any functions in the Perl API on that particular interpreter. This is done by calling the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PERL_SET_CONTEXT macro in that thread as the first thing you do:

  1. 	/* do this before doing anything else with some_perl */
  2. 	PERL_SET_CONTEXT(some_perl);
  4. 	... other Perl API calls on some_perl go here ...

Future Plans and PERL_IMPLICIT_SYS

Just as PERL_IMPLICIT_CONTEXT provides a way to bundle up everything that the interpreter knows about itself and pass it around, so too are there plans to allow the interpreter to bundle up everything it knows about the environment it's running on. This is enabled with the PERL_IMPLICIT_SYS macro. Currently it only works with USE_ITHREADS on Windows.

This allows the ability to provide an extra pointer (called the "host" environment) for all the system calls. This makes it possible for all the system stuff to maintain their own state, broken down into seven C structures. These are thin wrappers around the usual system calls (see win32/perllib.c) for the default perl executable, but for a more ambitious host (like the one that would do fork() emulation) all the extra work needed to pretend that different interpreters are actually different "processes", would be done here.

The Perl engine/interpreter and the host are orthogonal entities. There could be one or more interpreters in a process, and one or more "hosts", with free association between them.

Internal Functions

All of Perl's internal functions which will be exposed to the outside world are prefixed by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Perl_ so that they will not conflict with XS functions or functions used in a program in which Perl is embedded. Similarly, all global variables begin with http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_ . (By convention, static functions start with http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

S_ .)

Inside the Perl core (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PERL_CORE defined), you can get at the functions either with or without the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Perl_ prefix, thanks to a bunch of defines that live in embed.h. Note that extension code should not set http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PERL_CORE ; this exposes the full perl internals, and is likely to cause breakage of the XS in each new perl release.

The file embed.h is generated automatically from embed.pl and embed.fnc. embed.pl also creates the prototyping header files for the internal functions, generates the documentation and a lot of other bits and pieces. It's important that when you add a new function to the core or change an existing one, you change the data in the table in embed.fnc as well. Here's a sample entry from that table:

  1.     Apd |SV**   |av_fetch   |AV* ar|I32 key|I32 lval

The second column is the return type, the third column the name. Columns after that are the arguments. The first column is a set of flags:

  • A

    This function is a part of the public API. All such functions should also have 'd', very few do not.

  • p

    This function has a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    Perl_ prefix; i.e. it is defined as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    Perl_av_fetch .

  • d

    This function has documentation using the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    apidoc feature which we'll look at in a second. Some functions have 'd' but not 'A'; docs are good.

Other available flags are:

  • s

    This is a static function and is defined as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    STATIC S_whatever , and usually called within the sources as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    whatever(...) .

  • n

    This does not need an interpreter context, so the definition has no http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    pTHX , and it follows that callers don't use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    aTHX . (See Background and PERL_IMPLICIT_CONTEXT.)

  • r

    This function never returns; http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    croak , exit and friends.

  • f

    This function takes a variable number of arguments, printf style. The argument list should end with http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    ... , like this:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        Afprd   |void   |croak          |const char* pat|...
  • M

    This function is part of the experimental development API, and may change or disappear without notice.

  • o

    This function should not have a compatibility macro to define, say, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    Perl_parse to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    parse . It must be called as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    Perl_parse .

  • x

    This function isn't exported out of the Perl core.

  • m

    This is implemented as a macro.

  • X

    This function is explicitly exported.

  • E

    This function is visible to extensions included in the Perl core.

  • b

    Binary backward compatibility; this function is a macro but also has a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    Perl_ implementation (which is exported).

  • others

    See the comments at the top of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    embed.fnc for others.

If you edit embed.pl or embed.fnc, you will need to run http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

make regen_headers to force a rebuild of embed.h and other auto-generated files.

Formatted Printing of IVs, UVs, and NVs

If you are printing IVs, UVs, or NVS instead of the stdio(3) style formatting codes like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

%d , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

%ld , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

%f , you should use the following macros for portability

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

        IVdf            IV in decimal
        UVuf            UV in decimal
        UVof            UV in octal
        UVxf            UV in hexadecimal
        NVef            NV %e-like
        NVff            NV %f-like
        NVgf            NV %g-like

These will take care of 64-bit integers and long doubles. For example:

  1.         printf("IV is %"IVdf"\n", iv);

The IVdf will expand to whatever is the correct format for the IVs.

Note that there are different "long doubles": Perl will use whatever the compiler has.

If you are printing addresses of pointers, use UVxf combined with PTR2UV(), do not use %lx or %p.

Pointer-To-Integer and Integer-To-Pointer

Because pointer size does not necessarily equal integer size, use the follow macros to do it right.

  1.         PTR2UV(pointer)
  2.         PTR2IV(pointer)
  3.         PTR2NV(pointer)
  4.         INT2PTR(pointertotype, integer)

For example:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

        IV  iv = ...;
        SV *sv = INT2PTR(SV*, iv);

and

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

        AV *av = ...;
        UV  uv = PTR2UV(av);

Exception Handling

There are a couple of macros to do very basic exception handling in XS modules. You have to define http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

NO_XSLOCKS before including XSUB.h to be able to use these macros:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

        #define NO_XSLOCKS
        #include "XSUB.h"

You can use these macros if you call code that may croak, but you need to do some cleanup before giving control back to Perl. For example:

  1.         dXCPT;    /* set up necessary variables */
  3.         XCPT_TRY_START {
  4.           code_that_may_croak();
  5.         } XCPT_TRY_END
  7.         XCPT_CATCH
  8.         {
  9.           /* do cleanup here */
  10.           XCPT_RETHROW;
  11.         }

Note that you always have to rethrow an exception that has been caught. Using these macros, it is not possible to just catch the exception and ignore it. If you have to ignore the exception, you have to use the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

call_* function.

The advantage of using the above macros is that you don't have to setup an extra function for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

call_* , and that using these macros is faster than using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

call_* .

Source Documentation

There's an effort going on to document the internal functions and automatically produce reference manuals from them -- perlapi is one such manual which details all the functions which are available to XS writers. perlintern is the autogenerated manual for the functions which are not part of the API and are supposedly for internal use only.

Source documentation is created by putting POD comments into the C source, like this:

  1.  /*
  2.  =for apidoc sv_setiv
  4.  Copies an integer into the given SV.  Does not handle 'set' magic.  See
  5.  L<perlapi/sv_setiv_mg>.
  7.  =cut
  8.  */

Please try and supply some documentation if you add functions to the Perl core.

Backwards compatibility

The Perl API changes over time. New functions are added or the interfaces of existing functions are changed. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Devel::PPPort module tries to provide compatibility code for some of these changes, so XS writers don't have to code it themselves when supporting multiple versions of Perl.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Devel::PPPort generates a C header file ppport.h that can also be run as a Perl script. To generate ppport.h, run:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    perl -MDevel::PPPort -eDevel::PPPort::WriteFile

Besides checking existing XS code, the script can also be used to retrieve compatibility information for various API calls using the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

--api-info command line switch. For example:

  1.   % perl ppport.h --api-info=sv_magicext

For details, see http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

perldoc ppport.h .

Unicode Support

Perl 5.6.0 introduced Unicode support. It's important for porters and XS writers to understand this support and make sure that the code they write does not corrupt Unicode data.

What is Unicode, anyway?

In the olden, less enlightened times, we all used to use ASCII. Most of us did, anyway. The big problem with ASCII is that it's American. Well, no, that's not actually the problem; the problem is that it's not particularly useful for people who don't use the Roman alphabet. What used to happen was that particular languages would stick their own alphabet in the upper range of the sequence, between 128 and 255. Of course, we then ended up with plenty of variants that weren't quite ASCII, and the whole point of it being a standard was lost.

Worse still, if you've got a language like Chinese or Japanese that has hundreds or thousands of characters, then you really can't fit them into a mere 256, so they had to forget about ASCII altogether, and build their own systems using pairs of numbers to refer to one character.

To fix this, some people formed Unicode, Inc. and produced a new character set containing all the characters you can possibly think of and more. There are several ways of representing these characters, and the one Perl uses is called UTF-8. UTF-8 uses a variable number of bytes to represent a character. You can learn more about Unicode and Perl's Unicode model in perlunicode.

(On EBCDIC platforms, Perl uses instead UTF-EBCDIC, which is a form of UTF-8 adapted for EBCDIC platforms. Below, we just talk about UTF-8. UTF-EBCDIC is like UTF-8, but the details are different. The macros hide the differences from you, just remember that the particular numbers and bit patterns presented below will differ in UTF-EBCDIC.)

How can I recognise a UTF-8 string?

You can't. This is because UTF-8 data is stored in bytes just like non-UTF-8 data. The Unicode character 200, (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

0xC8 for you hex types) capital E with a grave accent, is represented by the two bytes http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

v196.172 . Unfortunately, the non-Unicode string chr(196).chr(172) has that byte sequence as well. So you can't tell just by looking -- this is what makes Unicode input an interesting problem.

In general, you either have to know what you're dealing with, or you have to guess. The API function http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

is_utf8_string can help; it'll tell you if a string contains only valid UTF-8 characters, and the chances of a non-UTF-8 string looking like valid UTF-8 become very small very quickly with increasing string length. On a character-by-character basis, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

isUTF8_CHAR will tell you whether the current character in a string is valid UTF-8.

How does UTF-8 represent Unicode characters?

As mentioned above, UTF-8 uses a variable number of bytes to store a character. Characters with values 0...127 are stored in one byte, just like good ol' ASCII. Character 128 is stored as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

v194.128 ; this continues up to character 191, which is http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

v194.191 . Now we've run out of bits (191 is binary http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

10111111 ) so we move on; character 192 is http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

v195.128 . And so it goes on, moving to three bytes at character 2048. Unicode Encodings in perlunicode has pictures of how this works.

Assuming you know you're dealing with a UTF-8 string, you can find out how long the first character in it is with the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

UTF8SKIP macro:

  1.     char *utf = "\305\233\340\240\201";
  2.     I32 len;
  4.     len = UTF8SKIP(utf); /* len is 2 here */
  5.     utf += len;
  6.     len = UTF8SKIP(utf); /* len is 3 here */

Another way to skip over characters in a UTF-8 string is to use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

utf8_hop , which takes a string and a number of characters to skip over. You're on your own about bounds checking, though, so don't use it lightly.

All bytes in a multi-byte UTF-8 character will have the high bit set, so you can test if you need to do something special with this character like this (the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

UTF8_IS_INVARIANT() is a macro that tests whether the byte is encoded as a single byte even in UTF-8):

  1.     U8 *utf;
  2.     U8 *utf_end; /* 1 beyond buffer pointed to by utf */
  3.     UV uv;	/* Note: a UV, not a U8, not a char */
  4.     STRLEN len; /* length of character in bytes */
  6.     if (!UTF8_IS_INVARIANT(*utf))
  7.         /* Must treat this as UTF-8 */
  8.         uv = utf8_to_uvchr_buf(utf, utf_end, &len);
  9.     else
  10.         /* OK to treat this character as a byte */
  11.         uv = *utf;

You can also see in that example that we use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

utf8_to_uvchr_buf to get the value of the character; the inverse function http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

uvchr_to_utf8 is available for putting a UV into UTF-8:

  1.     if (!UVCHR_IS_INVARIANT(uv))
  2.         /* Must treat this as UTF8 */
  3.         utf8 = uvchr_to_utf8(utf8, uv);
  4.     else
  5.         /* OK to treat this character as a byte */
  6.         *utf8++ = uv;

You must convert characters to UVs using the above functions if you're ever in a situation where you have to match UTF-8 and non-UTF-8 characters. You may not skip over UTF-8 characters in this case. If you do this, you'll lose the ability to match hi-bit non-UTF-8 characters; for instance, if your UTF-8 string contains http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

v196.172 , and you skip that character, you can never match a chr(200) in a non-UTF-8 string. So don't do that!

(Note that we don't have to test for invariant characters in the examples above. The functions work on any well-formed UTF-8 input. It's just that its faster to avoid the function overhead when it's not needed.)

How does Perl store UTF-8 strings?

Currently, Perl deals with UTF-8 strings and non-UTF-8 strings slightly differently. A flag in the SV, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SVf_UTF8 , indicates that the string is internally encoded as UTF-8. Without it, the byte value is the codepoint number and vice versa. This flag is only meaningful if the SV is http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvPOK or immediately after stringification via http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvPV or a similar macro. You can check and manipulate this flag with the following macros:

  1.     SvUTF8(sv)
  2.     SvUTF8_on(sv)
  3.     SvUTF8_off(sv)

This flag has an important effect on Perl's treatment of the string: if UTF-8 data is not properly distinguished, regular expressions, length, substr and other string handling operations will have undesirable (wrong) results.

The problem comes when you have, for instance, a string that isn't flagged as UTF-8, and contains a byte sequence that could be UTF-8 -- especially when combining non-UTF-8 and UTF-8 strings.

Never forget that the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SVf_UTF8 flag is separate from the PV value; you need to be sure you don't accidentally knock it off while you're manipulating SVs. More specifically, you cannot expect to do this:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    SV *sv;
    SV *nsv;
    STRLEN len;
    char *p;

    p = SvPV(sv, len);
    frobnicate(p);
    nsv = newSVpvn(p, len);

The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

char* string does not tell you the whole story, and you can't copy or reconstruct an SV just by copying the string value. Check if the old SV has the UTF8 flag set (after the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SvPV call), and act accordingly:

  1.     p = SvPV(sv, len);
  2.     is_utf8 = SvUTF8(sv);
  3.     frobnicate(p, is_utf8);
  4.     nsv = newSVpvn(p, len);
  5.     if (is_utf8)
  6.         SvUTF8_on(nsv);

In the above, your http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

frobnicate function has been changed to be made aware of whether or not it's dealing with UTF-8 data, so that it can handle the string appropriately.

Since just passing an SV to an XS function and copying the data of the SV is not enough to copy the UTF8 flags, even less right is just passing a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

char * to an XS function.

For full generality, use the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml> perltidy perltidy DO_UTF8 macro to see if the string in an SV is to be treated as UTF-8. This takes into account if the call to the XS function is being made from within the scope of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml> perltidy perltidy use bytes . If so, the underlying bytes that comprise the UTF-8 string are to be exposed, rather than the character they represent. But this pragma should only really be used for debugging and perhaps low-level testing at the byte level. Hence most XS code need not concern itself with this, but various areas of the perl core do need to support it.

And this isn't the whole story. Starting in Perl v5.12, strings that aren't encoded in UTF-8 may also be treated as Unicode under various conditions (see ASCII Rules versus Unicode Rules in perlunicode). This is only really a problem for characters whose ordinals are between 128 and 255, and their behavior varies under ASCII versus Unicode rules in ways that your code cares about (see The Unicode Bug in perlunicode). There is no published API for dealing with this, as it is subject to change, but you can look at the code for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_lc in pp.c for an example as to how it's currently done.

How do I convert a string to UTF-8?

If you're mixing UTF-8 and non-UTF-8 strings, it is necessary to upgrade the non-UTF-8 strings to UTF-8. If you've got an SV, the easiest way to do this is:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    sv_utf8_upgrade(sv);

However, you must not do this, for example:

  1.     if (!SvUTF8(left))
  2.         sv_utf8_upgrade(left);

If you do this in a binary operator, you will actually change one of the strings that came into the operator, and, while it shouldn't be noticeable by the end user, it can cause problems in deficient code.

Instead, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

bytes_to_utf8 will give you a UTF-8-encoded copy of its string argument. This is useful for having the data available for comparisons and so on, without harming the original SV. There's also http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

utf8_to_bytes to go the other way, but naturally, this will fail if the string contains any characters above 255 that can't be represented in a single byte.

How do I compare strings?

sv_cmp in perlapi and sv_cmp_flags in perlapi do a lexigraphic comparison of two SV's, and handle UTF-8ness properly. Note, however, that Unicode specifies a much fancier mechanism for collation, available via the Unicode::Collate module.

To just compare two strings for equality/non-equality, you can just use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml> perltidy perltidy memEQ() and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml> perltidy perltidy memNE() as usual, except the strings must be both UTF-8 or not UTF-8 encoded.

To compare two strings case-insensitively, use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml> perltidy perltidy foldEQ_utf8() (the strings don't have to have the same UTF-8ness).

Is there anything else I need to know?

Not really. Just remember these things:

  • There's no way to tell if a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    char * or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    U8 * string is UTF-8 or not. But you can tell if an SV is to be treated as UTF-8 by calling http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    DO_UTF8 on it, after stringifying it with http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvPV or a similar macro. And, you can tell if SV is actually UTF-8 (even if it is not to be treated as such) by looking at its http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SvUTF8 flag (again after stringifying it). Don't forget to set the flag if something should be UTF-8. Treat the flag as part of the PV, even though it's not -- if you pass on the PV to somewhere, pass on the flag too.

  • If a string is UTF-8, always use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    utf8_to_uvchr_buf to get at the value, unless http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    UTF8_IS_INVARIANT(*s) in which case you can use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    *s .

  • When writing a character UV to a UTF-8 string, always use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    uvchr_to_utf8 , unless UVCHR_IS_INVARIANT(uv)) in which case you can use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    *s = uv .

  • Mixing UTF-8 and non-UTF-8 strings is tricky. Use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    bytes_to_utf8 to get a new string which is UTF-8 encoded, and then combine them.

Custom Operators

Custom operator support is an experimental feature that allows you to define your own ops. This is primarily to allow the building of interpreters for other languages in the Perl core, but it also allows optimizations through the creation of "macro-ops" (ops which perform the functions of multiple ops which are usually executed together, such as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

gvsv, gvsv, add .)

This feature is implemented as a new op type, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

OP_CUSTOM . The Perl core does not "know" anything special about this op type, and so it will not be involved in any optimizations. This also means that you can define your custom ops to be any op structure -- unary, binary, list and so on -- you like.

It's important to know what custom operators won't do for you. They won't let you add new syntax to Perl, directly. They won't even let you add new keywords, directly. In fact, they won't change the way Perl compiles a program at all. You have to do those changes yourself, after Perl has compiled the program. You do this either by manipulating the op tree using a CHECK block and the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

B::Generate module, or by adding a custom peephole optimizer with the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

optimize module.

When you do this, you replace ordinary Perl ops with custom ops by creating ops with the type http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

OP_CUSTOM and the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

op_ppaddr of your own PP function. This should be defined in XS code, and should look like the PP ops in pp_*.c. You are responsible for ensuring that your op takes the appropriate number of values from the stack, and you are responsible for adding stack marks if necessary.

You should also "register" your op with the Perl interpreter so that it can produce sensible error and warning messages. Since it is possible to have multiple custom ops within the one "logical" op type http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

OP_CUSTOM , Perl uses the value of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

o->op_ppaddr to determine which custom op it is dealing with. You should create an http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

XOP structure for each ppaddr you use, set the properties of the custom op with http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

XopENTRY_set , and register the structure against the ppaddr using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

Perl_custom_op_register . A trivial example might look like:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    static XOP my_xop;
    static OP *my_pp(pTHX);

    BOOT:
        XopENTRY_set(&my_xop, xop_name, "myxop");
        XopENTRY_set(&my_xop, xop_desc, "Useless custom op");
        Perl_custom_op_register(aTHX_ my_pp, &my_xop);

The available fields in the structure are:

  • xop_name

    A short name for your op. This will be included in some error messages, and will also be returned as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $op->name by the B module, so it will appear in the output of module like B::Concise.

  • xop_desc

    A short description of the function of the op.

  • xop_class

    Which of the various http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    *OP structures this op uses. This should be one of the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    OA_* constants from op.h, namely

    • OA_BASEOP
    • OA_UNOP
    • OA_BINOP
    • OA_LOGOP
    • OA_LISTOP
    • OA_PMOP
    • OA_SVOP
    • OA_PADOP
    • OA_PVOP_OR_SVOP

      This should be interpreted as 'http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      PVOP ' only. The http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      _OR_SVOP is because the only core http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      PVOP , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      OP_TRANS , can sometimes be a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      SVOP instead.

    • OA_LOOP
    • OA_COP

    The other http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    OA_* constants should not be used.

  • xop_peep

    This member is of type http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    Perl_cpeep_t , which expands to void (*Perl_cpeep_t)(aTHX_ OP *o, OP *oldop). If it is set, this function will be called from http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    Perl_rpeep when ops of this type are encountered by the peephole optimizer. o is the OP that needs optimizing; oldop is the previous OP optimized, whose http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    op_next points to o.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

B::Generate directly supports the creation of custom ops by name.

Dynamic Scope and the Context Stack

Note: this section describes a non-public internal API that is subject to change without notice.

Introduction to the context stack

In Perl, dynamic scoping refers to the runtime nesting of things like subroutine calls, evals etc, as well as the entering and exiting of block scopes. For example, the restoring of a localised variable is determined by the dynamic scope.

Perl tracks the dynamic scope by a data structure called the context stack, which is an array of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PERL_CONTEXT structures, and which is itself a big union for all the types of context. Whenever a new scope is entered (such as a block, a for loop, or a subroutine call), a new context entry is pushed onto the stack. Similarly when leaving a block or returning from a subroutine call etc. a context is popped. Since the context stack represents the current dynamic scope, it can be searched. For example, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

next LABEL searches back through the stack looking for a loop context that matches the label; return pops contexts until it finds a sub or eval context or similar; caller examines sub contexts on the stack.

Each context entry is labelled with a context type, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_type . Typical context types are http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_SUB , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_EVAL etc., as well as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_BLOCK and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_NULL which represent a basic scope (as pushed by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_enter ) and a sort block. The type determines which part of the context union are valid.

The main division in the context struct is between a substitution scope (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_SUBST ) and block scopes, which are everything else. The former is just used while executing s///e, and won't be discussed further here.

All the block scope types share a common base, which corresponds to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_BLOCK . This stores the old values of various scope-related variables like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_curpm , as well as information about the current scope, such as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

gimme . On scope exit, the old variables are restored.

Particular block scope types store extra per-type information. For example, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_SUB stores the currently executing CV, while the various for loop types might hold the original loop variable SV. On scope exit, the per-type data is processed; for example the CV has its reference count decremented, and the original loop variable is restored.

The macro http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cxstack returns the base of the current context stack, while http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cxstack_ix is the index of the current frame within that stack.

In fact, the context stack is actually part of a stack-of-stacks system; whenever something unusual is done such as calling a DESTROY or tie handler, a new stack is pushed, then popped at the end.

Note that the API described here changed considerably in perl 5.24; prior to that, big macros like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PUSHBLOCK and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

POPSUB were used; in 5.24 they were replaced by the inline static functions described below. In addition, the ordering and detail of how these macros/function work changed in many ways, often subtly. In particular they didn't handle saving the savestack and temps stack positions, and required additional http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

ENTER , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

SAVETMPS and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

LEAVE compared to the new functions. The old-style macros will not be described further.

Pushing contexts

For pushing a new context, the two basic functions are http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx = cx_pushblock() , which pushes a new basic context block and returns its address, and a family of similar functions with names like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushsub(cx) which populate the additional type-dependent fields in the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx struct. Note that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_NULL and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_BLOCK don't have their own push functions, as they don't store any data beyond that pushed by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock .

The fields of the context struct and the arguments to the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_* functions are subject to change between perl releases, representing whatever is convenient or efficient for that release.

A typical context stack pushing can be found in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_entersub ; the following shows a simplified and stripped-down example of a non-XS call, along with comments showing roughly what each function does.

  1.  dMARK;
  2.  U8 gimme      = GIMME_V;
  3.  bool hasargs  = cBOOL(PL_op->op_flags & OPf_STACKED);
  4.  OP *retop     = PL_op->op_next;
  5.  I32 old_ss_ix = PL_savestack_ix;
  6.  CV *cv        = ....;
  8.  /* ... make mortal copies of stack args which are PADTMPs here ... */
  10.  /* ... do any additional savestack pushes here ... */
  12.  /* Now push a new context entry of type 'CXt_SUB'; initially just
  13.   * doing the actions common to all block types: */
  15.  cx = cx_pushblock(CXt_SUB, gimme, MARK, old_ss_ix);
  17.      /* this does (approximately):
  18.          CXINC;              /* cxstack_ix++ (grow if necessary) */
  19.          cx = CX_CUR();      /* and get the address of new frame */
  20.          cx->cx_type        = CXt_SUB;
  21.          cx->blk_gimme      = gimme;
  22.          cx->blk_oldsp      = MARK - PL_stack_base;
  23.          cx->blk_oldsaveix  = old_ss_ix;
  24.          cx->blk_oldcop     = PL_curcop;
  25.          cx->blk_oldmarksp  = PL_markstack_ptr - PL_markstack;
  26.          cx->blk_oldscopesp = PL_scopestack_ix;
  27.          cx->blk_oldpm      = PL_curpm;
  28.          cx->blk_old_tmpsfloor = PL_tmps_floor;
  30.          PL_tmps_floor        = PL_tmps_ix;
  31.      */
  34.  /* then update the new context frame with subroutine-specific info,
  35.   * such as the CV about to be executed: */
  37.  cx_pushsub(cx, cv, retop, hasargs);
  39.      /* this does (approximately):
  40.          cx->blk_sub.cv          = cv;
  41.          cx->blk_sub.olddepth    = CvDEPTH(cv);
  42.          cx->blk_sub.prevcomppad = PL_comppad;
  43.          cx->cx_type            |= (hasargs) ? CXp_HASARGS : 0;
  44.          cx->blk_sub.retop       = retop;
  45.          SvREFCNT_inc_simple_void_NN(cv);
  46.      */

Note that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock() sets two new floors: for the args stack (to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

MARK ) and the temps stack (to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_tmps_ix ). While executing at this scope level, every http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

nextstate (amongst others) will reset the args and tmps stack levels to these floors. Note that since http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock uses the current value of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_tmps_ix rather than it being passed as an arg, this dictates at what point http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock should be called. In particular, any new mortals which should be freed only on scope exit (rather than at the next http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

nextstate ) should be created first.

Most callers of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock simply set the new args stack floor to the top of the previous stack frame, but for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_LOOP_LIST it stores the items being iterated over on the stack, and so sets http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

blk_oldsp to the top of these items instead. Note that, contrary to its name, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

blk_oldsp doesn't always represent the value to restore http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_stack_sp to on scope exit.

Note the early capture of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_savestack_ix to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

old_ss_ix , which is later passed as an arg to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock . In the case of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_entersub , this is because, although most values needing saving are stored in fields of the context struct, an extra value needs saving only when the debugger is running, and it doesn't make sense to bloat the struct for this rare case. So instead it is saved on the savestack. Since this value gets calculated and saved before the context is pushed, it is necessary to pass the old value of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_savestack_ix to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock , to ensure that the saved value gets freed during scope exit. For most users of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock , where nothing needs pushing on the save stack, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_savestack_ix is just passed directly as an arg to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock .

Note that where possible, values should be saved in the context struct rather than on the save stack; it's much faster that way.

Normally http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock should be immediately followed by the appropriate http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushfoo , with nothing between them; this is because if code in-between could die (e.g. a warning upgraded to fatal), then the context stack unwinding code in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dounwind would see (in the example above) a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_SUB context frame, but without all the subroutine-specific fields set, and crashes would soon ensue.

Where the two must be separate, initially set the type to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_NULL or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_BLOCK , and later change it to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CXt_foo when doing the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushfoo . This is exactly what http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_enteriter does, once it's determined which type of loop it's pushing.

Popping contexts

Contexts are popped using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_popsub() etc. and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_popblock() . Note however, that unlike http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_pushblock , neither of these functions actually decrement the current context stack index; this is done separately using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CX_POP() .

There are two main ways that contexts are popped. During normal execution as scopes are exited, functions like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_leave , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_leaveloop and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_leavesub process and pop just one context using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_popfoo and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_popblock . On the other hand, things like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_return and next may have to pop back several scopes until a sub or loop context is found, and exceptions (such as die) need to pop back contexts until an eval context is found. Both of these are accomplished by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dounwind() , which is capable of processing and popping all contexts above the target one.

Here is a typical example of context popping, as found in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_leavesub (simplified slightly):

  1.  U8 gimme;
  2.  PERL_CONTEXT *cx;
  3.  SV **oldsp;
  4.  OP *retop;
  6.  cx = CX_CUR();
  8.  gimme = cx->blk_gimme;
  9.  oldsp = PL_stack_base + cx->blk_oldsp; /* last arg of previous frame */
  11.  if (gimme == G_VOID)
  12.      PL_stack_sp = oldsp;
  13.  else
  14.      leave_adjust_stacks(oldsp, oldsp, gimme, 0);
  16.  CX_LEAVE_SCOPE(cx);
  17.  cx_popsub(cx);
  18.  cx_popblock(cx);
  19.  retop = cx->blk_sub.retop;
  20.  CX_POP(cx);
  22.  return retop;

The steps above are in a very specific order, designed to be the reverse order of when the context was pushed. The first thing to do is to copy and/or protect any any return arguments and free any temps in the current scope. Scope exits like an rvalue sub normally return a mortal copy of their return args (as opposed to lvalue subs). It is important to make this copy before the save stack is popped or variables are restored, or bad things like the following can happen:

  1.     sub f { my $x =...; $x }  # $x freed before we get to copy it
  2.     sub f { /(...)/;    $1 }  # PL_curpm restored before $1 copied

Although we wish to free any temps at the same time, we have to be careful not to free any temps which are keeping return args alive; nor to free the temps we have just created while mortal copying return args. Fortunately, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

leave_adjust_stacks() is capable of making mortal copies of return args, shifting args down the stack, and only processing those entries on the temps stack that are safe to do so.

In void context no args are returned, so it's more efficient to skip calling http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

leave_adjust_stacks() . Also in void context, a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

nextstate op is likely to be imminently called which will do a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

FREETMPS , so there's no need to do that either.

The next step is to pop savestack entries: http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CX_LEAVE_SCOPE(cx) is just defined as <LEAVE_SCOPE(cx-blk_oldsaveix)>>. Note that during the popping, it's possible for perl to call destructors, call http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

STORE to undo localisations of tied vars, and so on. Any of these can die or call exit(). In this case, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dounwind() will be called, and the current context stack frame will be re-processed. Thus it is vital that all steps in popping a context are done in such a way to support reentrancy. The other alternative, of decrementing http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cxstack_ix before processing the frame, would lead to leaks and the like if something died halfway through, or overwriting of the current frame.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CX_LEAVE_SCOPE itself is safely re-entrant: if only half the savestack items have been popped before dying and getting trapped by eval, then the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CX_LEAVE_SCOPE s in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

dounwind or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_leaveeval will continue where the first one left off.

The next step is the type-specific context processing; in this case http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_popsub . In part, this looks like:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    cv = cx->blk_sub.cv;
    CvDEPTH(cv) = cx->blk_sub.olddepth;
    cx->blk_sub.cv = NULL;
    SvREFCNT_dec(cv);

where its processing the just-executed CV. Note that before it decrements the CV's reference count, it nulls the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

blk_sub.cv . This means that if it re-enters, the CV won't be freed twice. It also means that you can't rely on such type-specific fields having useful values after the return from http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_popfoo .

Next, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_popblock restores all the various interpreter vars to their previous values or previous high water marks; it expands to:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    PL_markstack_ptr = PL_markstack + cx->blk_oldmarksp;
    PL_scopestack_ix = cx->blk_oldscopesp;
    PL_curpm         = cx->blk_oldpm;
    PL_curcop        = cx->blk_oldcop;
    PL_tmps_floor    = cx->blk_old_tmpsfloor;

Note that it doesn't restore http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_stack_sp ; as mentioned earlier, which value to restore it to depends on the context type (specifically http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

for (list) {} ), and what args (if any) it returns; and that will already have been sorted out earlier by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

leave_adjust_stacks() .

Finally, the context stack pointer is actually decremented by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CX_POP(cx) . After this point, it's possible that that the current context frame could be overwritten by other contexts being pushed. Although things like ties and DESTROY are supposed to work within a new context stack, it's best not to assume this. Indeed on debugging builds, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CX_POP(cx) deliberately sets http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx to null to detect code that is still relying on the field values in that context frame. Note in the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_leavesub() example above, we grab http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

blk_sub.retop before calling http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

CX_POP .

Redoing contexts

Finally, there is http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

cx_topblock(cx) , which acts like a super-http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

nextstate as regards to resetting various vars to their base values. It is used in places like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_next , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_redo and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

pp_goto where rather than exiting a scope, we want to re-initialise the scope. As well as resetting http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_stack_sp like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

nextstate , it also resets http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_markstack_ptr , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_scopestack_ix and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

PL_curpm . Note that it doesn't do a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

FREETMPS .

With lots of help and suggestions from Dean Roehrich, Malcolm Beattie, Andreas Koenig, Paul Hudson, Ilya Zakharevich, Paul Marquess, Neil Bowers, Matthew Green, Tim Bunce, Spider Boardman, Ulrich Pfeifer, Stephen McCamant, and Gurusamy Sarathy.
